front: What is the purpose of the <blockquote> element in HTML?
back: To represent an extended quotation from another source, usually displayed as an indented block.

front: How do you attribute a source in a <blockquote> element?
back: Using the cite attribute (e.g., cite="https://example.com") to specify the URL of the source.

front: Does the cite attribute change how a <blockquote> looks in the browser?
back: No. It doesn't affect the visual presentation but provides metadata for screen readers and search engines.

front: What is the <cite> element used for?
back: To visually mark the title of a referenced work, such as a book, article, or film.

front: What's the difference between the <cite> element and the cite attribute?
back: <cite> is an element used for visible source titles; cite is an attribute used for hidden source metadata.

front: What is the purpose of the <q> element in HTML?
back: To mark a short, inline quotation within a paragraph. Browsers usually add quotation marks automatically.

front: Can the <q> element use the cite attribute?
back: Yes. It works like in <blockquote>—providing source metadata without affecting appearance.

front: What’s the main difference between <blockquote> and <q>?
back: <blockquote> is for long, standalone quotations. <q> is for short quotes within paragraphs.

front: When should you use a <blockquote> instead of a <q>?
back: Use <blockquote> for longer, multi-line or multi-paragraph quotes. Use <q> for brief, inline quotations.
